prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request an angular resolution which will allow us to place ~10 synthesized beams across each target. We request a sensitivity of 2mJy which should provide high snr detections of the gas in the central 10 kpc (e.g. Iono, Wilson, Yun et al 2009) and provides a reasonable balance with calibration overheads required. Note that the lines indicated in the text are not centered in the spectral windows, as we do not require high spectral resolution, and thus are able to spread the basebands over most of the available bandwidth in order to maintain the possibility of detecting additional lines to those mentioned in the text at no cost of time or sensitivity. This also allows us to spectrally average by a factor of four to reduce the data rate while maintaining a resolution better than 5 km/s.

We request a sensitivity of 2mJy which should provide high snr detections of the gas in the central 10 kpc (e.g. Iono, Wilson, Yun et al 2009) and provides a reasonable balance with calibration overheads required. Note that the lines indicated in the text are not centered in the spectral windows, as we do not require high spectral resolution, and thus are able to spread the basebands over most of the available bandwidth in order to maintain the possibility of detecting additional lines to those mentioned in the text at no cost of time or sensitivity. This also allows us to spectrally average by a factor of four to reduce the data rate while maintaining a resolution better than 5 km/s.

We request an angular resolution which will allow us to place ~10 synthesized beams across each target. We request a sensitivity of 2mJy which should provide high snr detections of the gas in the central 10 kpc (e.g. Iono, Wilson, Yun et al 2009) and provides a reasonable balance with calibration overheads required. The redshift of this source requires that we observe the CO(2-1) line rather than CO(3-2), but the goals remain the same as for the other targets. Note that the lines indicated in the text are not centered in the spectral windows, as we do not require high spectral resolution, and thus are able to spread the basebands over most of the available bandwidth in order to maintain the possibility of detecting additional lines to those mentioned in the text at no cost of time or sensitivity. This also allows us to spectrally average by a factor of four to reduce the data rate while maintaining a resolution ~5 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will observe the CO(3-2) in a representative sample of Compact Symmetric Objects that are attainable by ALMA to determine if the gas is disrupted, indicative of a recent merger, and to estimate the size of the gas reservoir available which will determine whether these compact radio sources might evolve into much larger FRII type sources, or whether their compact nature is due to being embedded in a dense environment. We expect to find enhancements in the CO emission toward the core if shocks are being driven into a dense ISM by compact radio jets, and we will look for additional tracers of shocked gas, such as SiO, SO2, CH3CN and CH3OH. These observations will allow us to determine whether the low ionization spectra of the galactic nuclei are due to starburst activity following a recent merger, to shocks resulting from the confinement of the radio jets in a dense environment, or to the low luminosity AGN.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy and the Institute for Astrophysics, New Mexico, University of
